2.text: Oh that my grief were thoroughly weighed, and all my calamity laid in the balances!

3.text: For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas; therefore my words are vehement.

4.text: For the arrows of the Almighty are within me, their poison drinketh up my spirit: the terrors of +God are arrayed against me.

5.text: Doth the wild ass bray by the grass? loweth an ox over his fodder?

6.text: Shall that which is insipid be eaten without salt? Is there any taste in the white of an egg?

7.text: What my soul refuseth to touch, that is as my loathsome food.

8.text: Oh that I might have my request, and that +God would grant my desire!

9.text: And that it would please +God to crush me, that he would let loose his hand and cut me off!

10.text: Then should I yet have comfort; and in the pain which spareth not I would rejoice that I have not denied the words of the Holy One.

11.text: What is my strength, that I should hope? and what is mine end, that I should have patience?

12.text: Is my strength the strength of stones? is my flesh of brass?

13.text: Is it not that there is no help in me, and soundness is driven away from me?

14.text: For him that is fainting kindness [is meet] from his friend; or he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.

15.text: My brethren have dealt deceitfully as a stream, as the channel of streams which pass away,

16.text: Which are turbid by reason of the ice, in which the snow hideth itself:

17.text: At the time they diminish, they are dried up; when heat affecteth them, they vanish from their place:

18.text: They wind about in the paths of their course, they go off into the waste and perish.

19.text: The caravans of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba counted on them:

20.text: They are ashamed at their hope; they come thither, and are confounded.

21.text: So now ye are nothing; ye see a terrible object and are afraid.

22.text: Did I say, Bring unto me, and make me a present from your substance?

23.text: Or, rescue me from the hand of the oppressor, and redeem me from the hand of the violent?

24.text: Teach me, and I will hold my tongue; and cause me to understand wherein I have erred.

25.text: How forcible are right words! but what doth your upbraiding reprove?

26.text: Do ye imagine to reprove words? The speeches of one that is desperate are indeed for the wind.

27.text: Yea, ye overwhelm the fatherless, and dig [a pit] for your friend.

28.text: Now therefore if ye will, look upon me; and it shall be to your face if I lie.

29.text: Return, I pray you, let there be no wrong; yea, return again, my righteousness shall be in it.

30.text: Is there wrong in my tongue? cannot my taste discern mischievous things?
